Award.AwardTitle: RNA Dynamics by Solution and Solid State Deuterium NMR

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to study dynamics in RNA by applying innovative magnetic resonance methods of solid and solution state NMR. The central hypothesis underlying this project is that motion is an essential aspect of RNA function: therefore, understanding the biological function of nucleic acids requires knowledge of the degree to which motions modulate molecular recognition by proteins and small molecules. By understanding its motions, the project will further understanding of the molecular recognition principles.

The new tools to study functional dynamics in nucleic acids developed through this project will be broadly applicable to other nucleic acid systems. Because the project is highly interdisciplinary, spanning biophysics, chemistry, molecular biology and pharmacology, it provides many opportunities for scientific collaborations and for exposing undergraduate and graduate students to interdisciplinary research, and for the training of under-represented minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RNA performs many biological functions in regulation of gene expression and disease. In many cases, its function depends on the ability to change structure in response to the binding of proteins or small ligands. By understanding how RNA moves at the atomic level, as we have done in executing this project, we clarify fundamental aspects of RNA structire-function and dynamics relationship, which are critical to understanding the biologial role of RNA but also to rationally design inhibitors of RNA function where it is believed to have therapeutic benefits.

We have studied RNA dynamics in a paradigmatic system, TAR RNA, which not only provides an outstanding example of the functional role of dynamics in RNA biology, but also of its importance in biomedicine, because it provides an inviting new target for biopharmaceuticals. By understanding RNA dynamics in this system that controls efficiency of transcription for the HIV virus, we would provide also important information on how to design better molecules to target this RNA.

Using a variary of experimental approaches, ranging from solution and solid state NMR to computational methods extended over very long periods of time (> 1 us), we have established rates of the conformational motions required for function and identified putative intermediate states through which the system transitions between its two stable conformational states. Thus, we have provided atomic insight into fundamental molecular events responsible for creating a structure that is responsible for recognition by the complex of viral and human proteins that activate transcription of HIV. In order to obtain these results, we have used new experimental approaches that will have broader application to other RNAs as well.


Last Modified: 04/17/2015
Modified by: Gabriele Varani
